newsitem.title: GERMANY: Rhoen-Klinikum ups forecast,may up dividend.
newsitem.headline: Rhoen-Klinikum ups forecast,may up dividend.

text.p: German hospital administrator Rhoen-Klinikum said on Thursday it had revised up its forecasts for 1997 sales and profit and said it was considering a marked increase in its dividend for the year.
The company said at a shareholder meeting that sales were expected to rise to 860 million marks ($478.7 million) this year and said it expected cash flow and profits to grow at a faster pace.
In May, the company said it expected full year sales to rise to 855 million marks and predicted a corresponding rate of profit growth.

For the first six months it reported group pre-tax profit of 63.26 million marks, up 24.5 percent from the previous year. Sales rose 18.4 percent to 428.6 million marks. In 1996, net profit rose by 30.2 percent to 46 million marks.
Parent company sales eased 3.3 percent to 104.4 million marks, but operating profit rose 12 percent to 22.27 million marks.

Friedrich Wilhelm Graf von Rittberg, head of the chairman's supervisory board, said the company planned to review its dividend policy and that a markedly higher dividend payout was possible for the occasion of the firm's 25th anniversary.
The review followed complaints from shareholders after the company failed to raise its dividend for 1996 due to worries about the impact of the German health reform bill.
Rhoen-Klinikum paid a dividend of 1.45 marks per preference share and 1.35 marks per ordinary share in 1996.
